The gunshots were the last thing you ever heard.

LineNo: 9524839,

Narrator: But he wasn't done speaking. Fo...
en


But he wasn't done speaking.\n\n"For the magnitude of the crimes you have committed against Sordland, I am sentencing you to life in prison."\n\nSoldiers grabbed your arms and started walking you towards the door. \n\nAs you were walking you...

en


Your whole world fell apart.

en


...congratulated him.

LineNo: 9525263,

Narrator: Your cell was cold and lonely. The...
en


Your cell was cold and lonely. The only decorations you put on the damp, dark walls were photos of Franc and Deana.\n\nFor a while, reading was the only thing you could do. After finishing the precious books sent by Monica, you kept yourself busy by writing your own memoir.\n\nYou were happy that at least your family was allowed to visit once a month.

LineNo: 9525269,

LineNo: 9525371,

...cried like a child.

en


...defiantly stood proud and strong.

LineNo: 9525575,

en


...felt relaxed. It was finally over.

LineNo: 9525677,

Narrator: Your cell was cold and lonely. A we...
en


Your cell was cold and lonely. A week remained until your execution.\n\nTo keep busy, you read books and occasionally scribbled down notes about your life that you hoped someone would compile into a memoir. It was better than just staring at the wall and waiting for your certain death.\n\nMonica visited you only once, along with the kids.

LineNo: 9525683,

Narrator: Your cell was cold and lonely. You...

Your cell was cold and lonely. You had a week until your execution.\n\nTo keep busy, you read books and occasionally scribbled down notes about your life that you hoped someone would compile into a memoir. It was better than just staring at the wall and waiting for your certain death.\n\nYou were happy that at least your family was allowed to visit you every day.

Franc visited you for the first time in years, bringing along his wife and son. They reminded you of your own family, in better times.\n\nYou held your grandson for the first time. He squirmed and started crying in your arms.\n\nFranc told you that he had joined the ranks of the Communist Party of Sordland. You...

LineNo: 9527387,

Narrator: The squad of soldiers turned the co...
en


The squad of soldiers turned the corner and lined up across from you. At the head of the line was their commander, Iosef.\n\nHe checked his watch and declared that the time had come. \n\nHe pulled out a cloth to cover your eyes.

LineNo: 9527503,

Player: ...said you were worried for his fu...
en


...said you were worried for his future.

LineNo: 9527605,

Narrator: But he wasn't finished speaking....
en


But he wasn't finished speaking.\n\n"For the magnitude of the crimes you have committed against Sordland, I am sentencing you to execution by firing squad."\n\nSoldiers grabbed your arms and started walking you towards the door. \n\nAs you were walking you...

LineNo: 9527723,

Player: You heard the footsteps of soldiers...
en


You heard the footsteps of soldiers approaching.

LineNo: 9527825,

...accepted your fate.

LineNo: 9528687,

Narrator: You were dragged outside after you...
en


You were dragged outside after you finished your final meal. Soldiers brought you to a corner just outside the prison block and tied your hands behind your back.\n\nYou took a look at the wall behind you. It was covered in dried blood.

LineNo: 9529073,

Narrator: Franc visited you for the first tim...
en


Franc visited you for the first time in years, bringing along his wife and son. They reminded you of your own family, in better times.\n\nYou held your grandson for the first time. He squirmed and started crying in your arms.\n\nFranc told you that he had joined the ranks of the People's Freedom and Justice Party. You...

1964|Antel Rock Prison

LineNo: 9529197,

Narrator: Your cell was cold and lonely. The...
en


Your cell was cold and lonely. The only decorations you put on the damp, dark walls were photos of Franc and Deana.\n\nFor a while, reading books was the only thing you could do. Eventually, you started scribbling notes about your life that you hoped you could turn into a memoir.\n\nMonica and the children visited only once, to have you sign the divorce papers.

LineNo: 9529203,

en


Time flies in jail.

en

LineNo: 9529611,

en

en


The week was over.

en


The day of your execution had arrived.\n\nThe cell door opened and the warden entered. He asked you what would be your final meal.\n\nYou asked him for...

LineNo: 9531051,

Narrator: The squad of soldiers turned the co...
en


The squad of soldiers turned the corner and lined up across from you. At the head of the line was their commander, Valken.\n\nHe checked his watch and declared that the time had come. \n\nHe pulled out a cloth to cover your eyes.

LineNo: 9531167,

Player: Beg Valken to free you.
en


Beg Valken to free you.

LineNo: 9531269,

Narrator: You learned in prison that after 2...
en


You learned in prison that after 2 years, the military junta finally gave the power back to people.\n\nThe political parties and the Grand National Assembly were re-established.\n\nYou...

LineNo: 9531275,

Narrator: You learned in prison that after 2...
Menu Text en


1960

LineNo: 9531393,

Player: ...did not care much.
en


...did not care much.

LineNo: 9531495,

Player: ...thought that this could be your...
en


...thought that this could be your way out.

Player: ...hoped that someone would hang Io...
en

LineNo: 9531977,

en


...hoped that someone would hang Valken for his crimes.

LineNo: 9532079,

Narrator: After 7 years in jail, Sordland's n...
en


After 7 years in jail, Sordland's new president finally granted amnesty to political prisoners from the military rule days.\n\nYou looked at yourself in the mirror as you were packing up your belongings to leave.

LineNo: 9532085,

Narrator: After 7 years in jail, Sordland's n...
Menu Text en


1965

LineNo: 9532187,

Player: You had grown old.
en


You had grown old.

LineNo: 9532289,

Narrator: Getting used to being a free man to...
en


Getting used to being a free man took years.\n\nYou finally felt confident enough to plan out what to do with the rest of your life.\n\nYou chose to...

LineNo: 9532295,

Narrator: Getting used to being a free man to...
Menu Text en


1967

LineNo: 9532413,

Narrator: You took your first step outside. F...
en


You took your first step outside. Freedom felt good.\n\nNo one was waiting for you.

LineNo: 9533077,

Narrator: You took your first step outside. F...
en


You took your first step outside. Freedom felt good.\n\nFranc and his family were waiting for you. \n\nEverything had changed so much that you felt out of place.

LineNo: 9533185,

Narrator: You took your first step outside. F...
en


You took your first step outside. Freedom felt good.\n\nMonica, Deana and Franc were waiting for you.\n\nUnfortunately, the years hadn't been kind to Monica.

LineNo: 9533293,

Narrator: You took your first step outside. F...
en


You took your first step outside. Freedom felt good.\n\nMonica and Deana were waiting for you.\n\nUnfortunately, the years hadn't been kind to Monica.

LineNo: 9533679,

Player: The years haven't been kind to you.
en


The years haven't been kind to you.

LineNo: 9533781,

Player: But they hadn't been kind to you ei...
en


But they hadn't been kind to you either.

LineNo: 9533883,

Player: ...have another shot at politics.
en


...have another shot at politics.

LineNo: 9533985,

Player: ...retire to the countryside.
en


...retire to the countryside.

LineNo: 9534087,

Player: ...find an earnest job.
en


...find an earnest job.

LineNo: 9534189,

Narrator: You tried to get back into politics...
en


You tried to get back into politics, but Sordland had changed too much.\n\nThe political spheres formed after the coup did not accept you.\n\nYou had to work menial, though at least honest, jobs to get by.

LineNo: 9534195,

Narrator: You tried to get back into politics...
Menu Text en


1973

LineNo: 9534297,

Narrator: Life was good. You took up vario...
en


Life was good.\n\nYou took up various hobbies like gardening and woodworking. Out of boredom, you became a carpenter.\n\nYour new past times earned you just enough money to get by.

LineNo: 9534303,

Narrator: Life was good. You took up vario...
Menu Text en


1973

LineNo: 9534405,

Player: At least you were free.
en


At least you were free.

LineNo: 9534507,

Narrator: Life was good. You took up woodw...
en


Life was good.\n\nYou took up woodworking and became a carpenter.\n\nIt was a menial job, but at least it was honest.

LineNo: 9534513,

Narrator: Life was good. You took up woodw...
Menu Text en


1973

LineNo: 9534615,

Player: You had all the time in the world.
en


You had all the time in the world.

LineNo: 9534717,

Player: You had to get by somehow.
en


You had to get by somehow.

LineNo: 9534819,

Narrator: A week after your 66th birthday, a...
en


A week after your 66th birthday, a woman knocked on your door.\n\nShe was a young upstart journalist fascinated by your life story. No matter what you did, she kept coming back. Finally, you gave in. She said she was working on a book about you. \n\nYou...

LineNo: 9534825,

Narrator: A week after your 66th birthday, a...
Menu Text en


1974

LineNo: 9534935,

Player: ...just wanted to finally have peac...
en


...just wanted to finally have peace of mind.

LineNo: 9535037,

Player: ...helped her as best as you could.
en


...helped her as best as you could.

LineNo: 9535139,

Narrator: After many hours of interviews, she...
en


After many hours of interviews, she said that she had enough information and disappeared from your life.\n\nYou looked up the name she had given you, but you couldn't find it anywhere. You suspected she'd used an alias.

LineNo: 9535247,

Player: You wondered why.
en


You wondered why.

LineNo: 9535349,

Narrator: You heard a knock on your door. It...
en


You heard a knock on your door. It was the delivery man with a large, heavy package.\n\nThe package was filled with copies of books. There was a small note on top of it.\n\n"Thank you. --Carol Circas"

LineNo: 9535457,

Player: You picked up the book.
en


You picked up the book.

LineNo: 9535559,

Narrator: It was titled Suzerain: The Story o...
en


It was titled Suzerain: The Story of Anton Rayne.

LineNo: 9535667,

Player: You faintly smiled.
en


You faintly smiled.

LineNo: 9535775,

Narrator: The warden paid you a visit to deli...
en


The warden paid you a visit to deliver a letter from the Sordish Armed Forces. You opened the envelope.\n\nFranc Rayne was killed in action in a battle against the BFF near Erzaren.

LineNo: 9535781,

Narrator: The warden paid you a visit to deli...
Menu Text en


1964|Antel Rock Prison
